The district site based decision committee adopted the 2020-2021 for recommendation to the school board.

This calendar is identical to the current school calendar with two exceptions. The bad weather day that traditionally follows Easter has been moved to Friday, April 23. The consequence for a positive nicotine sample will be ‚Äúparent notification‚Äù until January 1, 2020. The district will use the time until the new year to explore various consequences, receive public input, and educate our students on the dangers on nicotine.
Vaping has become a nationwide epidemic in high schools and Hamilton High School is no different. In its past legislative session, the Texas Legislature changed the legal smoking age from 18 to 21 to help get vaping out of high schools. This new law goes into effect September 1st. The Hamilton ISD school board will revisit the issue in November to update this policy after this ‚Äútrial period.‚Äù

As you know by now a water line was ruptured on the square here in Hamilton. Initially, water pressure at the school was reduced but still functional. However, as time passed, all three campuses were left without water. This made it necessary to release school an hour early.

I want to thank everyone in the community, parents and our staff for the cooperation we received on such short notice. We used several different methods to get the word out. Specifically, an Alert Now message (phone call & text message) was sent out by the district at approximately 2:15pm. If you have a child in the district and you did not receive the call or text, we ask that you update your contact information in writing to the campus office as soon as possible.

We realize this early release today was inconvenient and placed a burden on many families. Together we made it work. That is what makes this community such a great place!

Clay Tarpley
Superintendent

As you know by now a water line was ruptured on the square here in Hamilton. Initially, water pressure at the school was reduced but still functional. However, as time passed, all three campuses were left without water. This made it necessary to release school an hour early.

I want to thank everyone in the community, parents and our staff for the cooperation we received on such short notice. We used several different methods to get the word out. Specifically, an Alert Now message (phone call & text message) was sent out by the district at approximately 2:15pm. If you have a child in the district and you did not receive the call or text, we ask that you update your contact information in writing to the campus office as soon as possible.

We realize this early release today was inconvenient and placed a burden on many families. Together we made it work. That is what makes this community such a great place!

Clay Tarpley
Superintendent

On Thursday, March 9th at a special meeting, the Board of Trustees approved Gina Poe as the principal of Hamilton High School for the 2017-2018 school year. Mrs. Poe is currently serving as Hamilton ISD's Coordinator of Curriculum & Technology. She has also served as a principal in Clifton ISD and as an assistant principal at Ann Whitney Elementary in a previous stint with Hamilton.

Gina Poe has a master's degree and bachelor's degree from Tarleton State University. She is replacing Principal Louis Lowe who is retiring at the end of the current school year after five years at the helm.

There were 39 applicants for the high school principal's position.
